Law Enforcement Today Menu
Breaking News
UPS goes full ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, announces it will assist government in unconstitutional confiscation, destruction of gun parts
Posted by: Patrick Droney|July 3, 2022 |Categories2A Watch, Editorial, Featured, Must Reads
Share:
The following contains an embedded article which is editorial in nature and expresses the opinion of the writer.

‚Äî

NEW YORK- New York never learns its lesson.

Just days after getting its knees cut out from under it by the United States Supreme Court, Attorney General Letitia James and New York City Mayor Eric Adams announced a pair of lawsuits against companies that they wrongly claim sell untraceable firearms‚Äîaka ‚Äúghost guns‚Äù‚Äîwhich they say are responsible for many gun-related deaths.

This despite the fact that statistically, such guns account for a very small and declining portion of firearms seized by police officers, according to the New York Post.

Last Wednesday, James and Adams announced the filing of separate legal actions against vendors of the ‚Äúdo-it-yourself‚Äù weapons.

In the case of New York City, a lawsuit was filed against ten online gun retailers which Adams claims are illegally delivering ‚Äúghost gun‚Äù parts to addresses in the city.

The state‚Äôs lawsuit meanwhile contend that gun sellers from outside New York state have sold tens of thousands of gun parts that were allegedly turned into untraceable handguns and scary black weapons referred to as ‚Äúassault weapons.‚Äù

New York City officials said retailers in Missouri, Washington, Florida and North Carolina sold ‚Äúghost gun‚Äù kits to an investigator affiliated with the New York City Sheriff‚Äôs Office. It is alleged the gun parts were sent to a building in the city, which violates both city and state laws.

Article in full:

https://www.lawenforcementtoday.com/new-yorks-ag-nyc-mayor-file-suit-against-ghost-gun-makers-as-stunt/

card.title: Very detailed biography, refuting some but not all of the many myths about Stalin

_source.content: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/customer-reviews/R1HUXVAPCNC7GW/ref=cm_cr_dp_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=0691202710 Very detailed biography, refuting some but not all of the many myths about StalinIn this fascinating study, Suny demolishes some, but not all, of the many myths about Stalin.He points out that Stolypin carried out a coup d‚Äô√©tat of June 3, 1907. Then, ‚ÄúBy extra-constitutionally changing the franchise to over represent the landed nobility and propertied classes, Stolypin had acquired the parliament with which he believed he could work.‚ÄùSo, the Third Duma (1907-1912) was elected on a completely distorted franchise: ‚ÄúThe vast majority of Russia‚Äôs people had been effectively disenfranchised.‚Äù That is the way it stayed till the end of the feudal autocratic tsarist empire.Suny observes that ‚ÄúThe classical (what some would call ‚Äòorthodox‚Äô) Marxist view of the nation, as articulated by most Social Democrats of the early twentieth century, began with the supposition that nations were products of history, not of nature, and that they were generated by material processes such as the need for national markets, state policies protecting those markets, and long-distance trade. Therefore, nations were objective, real, material, not merely the product of consciousness or a national spirit (Geist). ‚Ä¶Nationalism, on the other hand, was a form of consciousness that arose as a nation was being formed, a subjective expression of the nation. This chronology - nation before nationalism - would be reversed in late twentieth-century nationalism theory in the work both of non-Marxists, like Elie Kedourie and Ernest Gellner, and Marxists, like Benedict Anderson and Eric Hobsbawm. They would propose that nations were a product of human action, of invention and imagination, as much if not more than of historical processes and greater social communication.‚ÄùLate twentieth-century nationalism theory was in fact just a reversion to discredited old idealist theory, that ideas not realities determine history. That Anderson and Hobsbawm agreed with liberal anti-Marxists like Kedourie and Gellner shows that Anderson and Hobsbawm had abandoned Marxism.Suny notes that ‚ÄúRosa Luxemburg ‚Ä¶ believed that Social Democrats should not defend the right of nations to self-determination since nations were kinds of fictions that in the real world were divided into classes.‚Äù So, Luxemburg agreed with the anti-Marxists. As a result, she opposed wars of national liberation, concluding absurdly that in the age of imperialism, ‚Äúnational wars can no longer exist.‚Äù

https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/customer-reviews/R1HUXVAPCNC7GW/ref=cm_cr_dp_d_rvw_ttl?ie=UTF8&ASIN=0691202710

Very detailed biography, refuting some but not all of the many myths about Stalin

In this fascinating study, Suny demolishes some, but not all, of the many myths about Stalin.

He points out that Stolypin carried out a coup d‚Äô√©tat of June 3, 1907. Then, ‚ÄúBy extra-constitutionally changing the franchise to over represent the landed nobility and propertied classes, Stolypin had acquired the parliament with which he believed he could work.‚Äù

So, the Third Duma (1907-1912) was elected on a completely distorted franchise: ‚ÄúThe vast majority of Russia‚Äôs people had been effectively disenfranchised.‚Äù That is the way it stayed till the end of the feudal autocratic tsarist empire.

Suny observes that ‚ÄúThe classical (what some would call ‚Äòorthodox‚Äô) Marxist view of the nation, as articulated by most Social Democrats of the early twentieth century, began with the supposition that nations were products of history, not of nature, and that they were generated by material processes such as the need for national markets, state policies protecting those markets, and long-distance trade. Therefore, nations were objective, real, material, not merely the product of consciousness or a national spirit (Geist). ‚Ä¶
Nationalism, on the other hand, was a form of consciousness that arose as a nation was being formed, a subjective expression of the nation. This chronology - nation before nationalism - would be reversed in late twentieth-century nationalism theory in the work both of non-Marxists, like Elie Kedourie and Ernest Gellner, and Marxists, like Benedict Anderson and Eric Hobsbawm. They would propose that nations were a product of human action, of invention and imagination, as much if not more than of historical processes and greater social communication.‚Äù

Late twentieth-century nationalism theory was in fact just a reversion to discredited old idealist theory, that ideas not realities determine history. That Anderson and Hobsbawm agreed with liberal anti-Marxists like Kedourie and Gellner shows that Anderson and Hobsbawm had abandoned Marxism.

Suny notes that ‚ÄúRosa Luxemburg ‚Ä¶ believed that Social Democrats should not defend the right of nations to self-determination since nations were kinds of fictions that in the real world were divided into classes.‚Äù So, Luxemburg agreed with the anti-Marxists. As a result, she opposed wars of national liberation, concluding absurdly that in the age of imperialism, ‚Äúnational wars can no longer exist.‚Äù

That is not the case.In the beginning, we were told, ‚ÄúNine out of ten vaccinated people will not get sick‚Äù (Columbia University feat. Run-DMC, Feb. 12, 2021 , no this is not a joke); ‚ÄúVaccinated people don't carry the virus, don't get sick‚Äù (Dr. Rochelle Walensky, March 29, 2021 ); ‚ÄúIf people are vaccinated, they can rest assured that they will not be infected‚Äù (Dr. Anthony Fauci, May 17, 2021 )And by mid-summer 2021, we were still being told that these vaccines were unequivocally a resounding success, worthy of uncritical support. On July 27, Dr. Eric Topol in Scientific American: "Vaccination is the closest thing to certainty we have in this pandemic." But what they can no longer do is prevent transmission‚ÄùWhile there is a mountain of medical literature out there that clearly shows that these vaccines fail to prevent infection and transmission, the August 5 statement from the CDC director should have made it clear...Read moirehttps://www.frontnieuws.com/de-onuitstaanbare-arrogantie-van-de-voortdurend-bij-het-verkeerde-eind-hebbende-vaccinzeloten/
_source.contentraw:
The insufferable arrogance of the constantly wrong vaccine zealots

The media, and the people who work in and around it, the Blue Checks‚Ñ¢ of Twitter, have in recent years raised the bar even higher in the degree to which they are willing to go to force the various narratives desired.

Pick any big story from the past three years ‚Äî e.g. lablek, Jussie Smollett, Russiagate, Ukrainian biolabs, Ivermectin, Covid vs. Covid hospitalizations, January 6, Transitory inflation, and of course Hunter's laptop ‚Äî and you'll find yourself absolutely hysterical. come to the fore, followed by retractions, corrections, and outright denials when reality became undeniable, writes Clayton Fox .

Meanwhile, our society was torn apart, our citizens were gaslighted and impoverished, and in countries all over the Western world, innocent people from the so-called civilized society were canceled, branded lepers, and fired from their jobs.

Why? Because there is one story that just won't die and for which no corrections have been made - the shibboleth that vaccination can prevent infection and transmission, and can help "end" COVID.

While there is never an excuse for hateful rhetoric against and interference in the personal medical choices of law-abiding people, perhaps one could understand the campaign a little if the new vaccines had provided long-lasting immunity and prevented transmission in society. That is not the case.

In the beginning, we were told, ‚ÄúNine out of ten vaccinated people will not get sick‚Äù (Columbia University feat. Run-DMC, Feb. 12, 2021 , no this is not a joke); ‚ÄúVaccinated people don't carry the virus, don't get sick‚Äù (Dr. Rochelle Walensky, March 29, 2021 ); ‚ÄúIf people are vaccinated, they can rest assured that they will not be infected‚Äù (Dr. Anthony Fauci, May 17, 2021 )

And by mid-summer 2021, we were still being told that these vaccines were unequivocally a resounding success, worthy of uncritical support. On July 27, Dr. Eric Topol in Scientific American: "Vaccination is the closest thing to certainty we have in this pandemic." Not to be outdone, Dr. NIAID's Anthony Fauci told CBS on Aug. 1 that the unvaccinated were responsible for "spreading this outbreak"

But on July 29, 2021, the Washington Post reported a first that the CDC privately acknowledged that the vaccinated could spread COVID as easily as the unvaccinated. Occasionally they are forced to report inconvenient facts. And on Aug. 5, CDC Director Walensky told CNN's Wolf Blitzer, ‚ÄúThey continue to work well for Delta, in terms of serious illness and death ‚Äî they're preventing it. But what they can no longer do is prevent transmission‚Äù

While there is a mountain of medical literature out there that clearly shows that these vaccines fail to prevent infection and transmission, the August 5 statement from the CDC director should have made it clear...
